An Expedition is rated for a number of characteristics: Crew, Cannon, Navigation, Discipline, Sailing, and Swashbuckling. Hazards that may be faced by the Expeditions include Spanish Galleons, Typhoons, Volcanic Eruptions, and Hostile Natives. The winner is the player who returns with the buried treasure.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37947.name: Greek Heroes
37947.description:
"Each player controls a Greek Hero on a Quest to retrieve the Golden Fleece."

Each Hero is rated for a number of skills, including Wit, Strength, Archery, Swordsmanship, and Navigation. These skills are used to overcome foes and tests which face the Heroes, such as the Minotaur, Kraken, Labyrinth, Amazons, and Hydra.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37948.name: Sharpe's Adventures
37948.description:
"Each player is a British Officer in Spain circa 1809. Based on the Sharpe’s Rifle Series of Books and Films by Bernard Cornwell." The players start out as Sergeants. The object of the game is to survive to reach the rank of Major.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37949.name: Into the Valley of Death
37949.description:
"Simulation of the Charge of the Light Brigade, the final phase of battle of Balaclava in 1854."

"The player controls a British cavalry group of 12 men known as a ‘Troop’. All men are mounted on horses. All men are armed with a sword. One of the men is the Captain, the leader of the troop. Another man is the Trumpeter. The other 10 men are referred to as riders. There are 3 types of Troops: Dragoons, Hussars, and Lancers." The player chooses which type of Troop to use.

The object of the game is to charge the Russian gun battery and return, scoring as many points as possible. Points are earned for each surviving man in the Troop and for overcoming challenges.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37950.name: Hidalgo
37950.description:
"Based on the Movie Hidalgo. Horse Race across the Arabian Desert. Each player (Pawn) represents a Rider & Horse."

The game is played on a track 50 spaces long, along which the players face survival and fighting challenges. The first player to reach the end of the track wins the race.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37951.name: Surviving the Gulag
37951.description:
"The year is 1947 and the player is an Estonian patriot and resistance fighter that has been caught by the Russians and transported to Siberia to a brutal labor camp. The sentence is ten years of horrific conditions. The player has to survive the camp to return to the beloved Estonia."

"Resistance Fighter, Kalle Loodus, 33 years of age, former corporal in the Estonian Army during the independence, fought in Finnish Army during the War of Continuation, after the war returned to the Soviets by Finnish communist traitors, escaped and fought as a 'Forest Brother Guerilla Fighter' until caught and sent to labor camp in Siberia."

Hardships that may face the player include Scurvy, Tuberculosis, Forced Labor, and Torture.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37952.name: War Over the Reich
37952.description:
"Each player controls a Flight of 300 British (Halifax, Wellington, Mosquito, and Lancaster) Bombers on a Night Raid to bomb targets in Nazi Germany."

The players must get their Flight to the target, bomb the target, and return. The object is to earn the most victory points. Victory points are awarded for destroying targets and destroying enemy fighters. Victory points are lost when bombers are destroyed.

A variant set of cards is included to cover American daylight bombing raids.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37953.name: Destroy the Rail Road Bridge
37953.description:
"The player controls a combat team of 5 Finnish Army Recon (Kaukopartio in Finnish) men in a mission far behind Soviet lines. The mission is to destroy a Rail Road Bridge 60 miles behind the enemy lines. It´s January 1943 and it's cold and dark in the Karelian woods."

"Each party consists of 5 members: Sergeant V.Korpi, Corpral J.Lahtinen, Jaeger M.Koskinen, Jaeger S.Berg, Jaeger S.Stenstrom. The Sergeant has 3 skills, Corpral has 2 skills and Jaegers have 1 skill. The combat team is armed with 5 Suomi SMG's, 1 Sniper Rifle, Satchel Charges (AT weapon), mines, knives (the puukko's) and hand grenades. The team is carrying a radio. The team is skiing 60 miles to the target and 60 miles back to the Finnish lines."

The object of the game is to get your team safely to the bridge so that you can destroy it and then return. "When the combat team reaches home, they take a good 3 hour sauna bath, sleep a little and start another mission."

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37954.name: Where Eagles Dared
37954.description:
"Movie 1968…. Commandos, posing as German soldiers, parachute into the Bavarian Alps to rescue a supposed allied general from a Nazi hideaway fortress that can only be reached by cable car. Epic war pic where Richard Burton and Clint Eastwood manage to unmask most of the German spy network in England, slip Jerry the wrong plans for the second front, kill the leading members of the Abwehr in Southern Bavaria, and destroy half of the local Wehrmacht."

Each player controls a Commando Team of seven agents - a major, an American Ranger lieutenant, two commandos, and three traitors. Other team members may be gained during play. The object of the game is to journey through the Alpine wilderness to the Castle of the Eagles, face three challenges, and then escape to a German airfield to be extracted in a disguised aircraft.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37955.name: In the Nam
37955.description:
"Your platoon has been de-assed in the bush. You must patrol the area and meet at a new pick-up point."

In this game set during the Vietnam War, each player starts with a platoon of forty-two men. The object of the game is to travel down the thirty space game track which abstractly represents time and distance. Along the way the platoon will face a variety of foes and booby traps. The object of the game is to amass the most Confirmed Kill points and survive with at least twenty men to be airlifted out.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37956.name: Alien Queen Brain
37956.description:
"The players control a squad of space Marines in charge of freeing a command post overrun by alien forces."

Each player controls a landing party of six marines, consisting of one leader, one sergeant, and four soldiers. Each marine has a randomly determined set of skills. Available skills include xeno-biology, computer, mechanics, ground navigation, and morale.

The parties must travel from the drop zone to the overrun command post. Inside the command post is the Alien Queen which must be defeated. The party must then return to the drop zone with the Alien Queen Brain.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37957.name: Beastmaster Quest
37957.description:
Each player is a Beastmaster, as depicted in the movie of the same name.

The object of the game is to be the first player to complete a Beastmaster Quest by reaching the last space on the sixty space game track. Along the way the players will face a variety of challenges, including treachery by the opposing Beastmasters.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37958.name: The Isle of Dread
37958.description:
"Based loosely on the old D&D Expert Rules system. This is a conversion of Dungeon Module X1 'The Isle of Dread'. Each player has an Adventuring Party in search of Adventure & Fortune. Each party is represented by a pawn on the track."

Each player controls a party of six adventurers. Each adventurer has a class (Fighter, Thief, Cleric, Magic User, Elf, Dwarf, or Halfling) and skills in three attributes (Stealth, Magic, and Fighting.)

The game is played on a track ninety spaces long, which abstractly represents distance and time. The game ends when the first party reaches the end space. The player who has the most gold at the end of the game wins.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37959.name: Palace of the Silver Princess
37959.description:
"This Warp Quest Adventure is adapted from the D&D Basic Adventure Module Palace of the Silver Princess."

Each player chooses to play one of the following characters: Human Paladin, Dwarf Fighter, Aasimar Cleric, Human Wizard, or Elf Bard. The winner is the first player to reach the end of the thirty space long track on the game board. Along the way the players will face randomly drawn traps and monsters.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37960.name: Rabbit Run
37960.description:
"Each player controls a Band of Rabbits who have left their overcrowded home Warren and are traveling the countryside, looking for a good spot to establish a new Warren. Based on the Novel Watership Down by Richard Adams."

The winner is the first player to have a band of rabbits reach the end the thirty-space game track.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37961.name: Constantine
37961.description:
"Based on the movie Constantine, which was based on the comic Hellblazer. Each player is a Demon-Hunter/Exorcist."

Each Hunter is rated for the following attributes: Hit Points, Psychic, Contacts, Willpower, Combat, and Morality. The Hunters use these attributes to face Fight, Mental, and Info challenges.

The game is played on a track fifty spaces long. "The last represents the culmination of an infernal plot. The first player to the last space foils the plot and wins the game."

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37962.name: Dantes Inferno
37962.description:
Each player controls a party consisting of three entities: a Renaissance poet, a blessed soul of heaven, and a pagan scholar holy soul. The party must undertake a quest to travel from Earth to hell, through the levels of hell, exiting into purgatoria, the last space on the board.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37963.name: Score
37963.description:
"Each player takes the role of a teenager looking to Score on a Saturday night."

The players move pawns down a thirty space track facing an assortment of challenges: alcohol, sex, drugs, music, trouble and fight. When you win a challenge, you keep the Challenge Card. The player who acquires the most cards in the most challenge types wins the game.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37964.name: Jail Break
37964.description:
"Each player takes the role of a prisoner in Dick J. Pitt Correctional Facility Medium Security Prison looking to escape through a tunnel the prisoner is digging from his cell to freedom and then driving to Mexico."

The game is played on a track sixty spaces long. The first thirty spaces represent arranging the escape from prison. The second thirty spaces represent the journey to Mexico. Cards are drawn to provide random challenges and assistance. A player who wins a challenge keeps the Challenge Card. The player who acquires the most cards in the most challenge types wins the game.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

37965.name: drakkar
37965.description:
Contents: a square board 13×13, 30 tokens with an emblem printed on a face (6 different emblems), 8 pawns, 2 dices.
Each player is given 5 emblems, and his goal is to capture 5 tokens of this emblems. He can play his pawns or his tokens accordingly to the dices. Each time a player plays a pawn upon a token, he chooses between two actions:
- to look secretly the emblem, then to put it back at his place, or
- to take the emblem by flipping it. If it reveals to be one of those the player is looking for, he keeps it, else he must stay in jail for two moves.

37966.name: VR Troopers Game
37966.description:
From the back of the box:

"He's nasty! He's mean! He's Grimlord, the power-hungry master of virtual reality. And he's about to launch a deadly attack on the real world. Only you can stop him!

You and your friends must transform into VR Troopers and enter the mysterious world of virtual reality - just like on the exciting TV show! Toss the battle dice top smash the sinister Skugs. Your powers increase as you defeat them. Then fight the fiendish robot mutant General Ivar! But watch out! He'll stop at nothing to destroy you!

Only the bravest VR Troupers can defeat Grimlord's evil army and win the game. Will it be you?"

Unlike most other games, the three VR warriors in the game are shared by the players. Each turn, the active player throws a die to decide which (red, yellow or green) trooper he controls this time, and then battle a Skug on their way to the penultimate battle, General Ivar.

Battles are done by tossing dice into a battle arena. Someone plays the Skug and tosses one die, hoping for a hit (50% chance), and then the active player tosses a die to get a hit as well. Play continues with 2 more dice on each side , one at a time. The dexterity comes in that you can try to hit your opponent's 'hit' die or your own 'miss' die to switch the result. Ties go to the active player.

There is some skill in tossing the dice to change results, but because you cannot control which VR warrior you will assumer on your turn, the game comes down mainly to luck. Winning battlers earns you a power chip (with a VR glasses wearing dog on it), which will allow you a reroll in the final battle (which is a toss of 4 dice at once, so dexterity plays no role here), while losing a battle loses you the same number of accumulated power chips.

There's no doubt this is a kid's game for fans of the TV show. Still, the components are fairly nice and the battle arena mechanic is well done.

37967.name: The Letter Carrier Game
37967.description:
"People play letter carriers and maneuver through situations that aid and hinder them in making all deliveries safely and efficiently."

The object of the game is to optimize the delivery path and be the first to finish.

The board is made up of sixteen two-sided square tiles, featuring neighborhoods named after U.S. municipalities. The game comes with 292 more pieces, including dice, hand-painted pawns, and "chance" cards, which feature obstacles (such as an angry dog), incidents (falling ice), transportation (bicycle), and helps (helmet).

Players can accumulate cards to help or sabotage an opponent.

The designer worked with his father, a retired letter carrier, to make the game as true-to-life as possible.

Home Page: http://lettercarriergame.com/

37969.description:
Die Siedler von Luxemburg is a scenario for the game The Settlers of Catan. It was created by the Luxemburg gaming club Guilde vun de Phantasiespiller for the national Catan championship 2008 and plays on a fixed map of the state of Luxemburg. The game includes the board, rules, and some additional components. A copy of Settlers is required for game play. Only 700 copies of the game were released, 300 of which were retained by Klaus Teuber and Kosmos for promotional events and corporate gifts.

Part of the Catan Series.
37969.name: Die Siedler von Luxemburg

37970.name: Sol Invictus: The Copernican Wars
37970.description:
War has spread throughout the solar system, with factions using gravimetrics, atomics, and psionics to aid troopers as they invade and conquer planets to gain supremacy.

Star Fleet is fractured, Earth Command has become a vast telepathic neural net, and the asteroid belt is prey to teracorporations who parley with the Interplanetary Space Stations for peace.

In the midst of it all, an alien artifact mysteriously appears beyond the dwarf planet Pluto.

It is time to conquer the solar system in wars of the future.

37971.description:
Defenders of ClayArt is a game designed and published by B2FGames in Tachikawa, Japan. This game is currently sold by retailers in Japan only but whole components and the rulebook are written in English planned for worldwide publishing, though not yet achieved as of Aug. 2008.

Introductory text from the rulebook:

At a gallery in the city, or a studio in the countryside, snobbish artists, each thinking of him/herself as a defender of art, bicker with each other over works of "art". Much ado about nothing.(Welcome to the world of art critics. No talent necessary!)
You, as one of these artists, criticize the works. If your critique is pointed, you win the honor of being the true defender of art.
In this game, the players make clay sculptures with a certain theme, and criticize (rather than review) them. You can earn points when your critique matches the others'. The player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.
37971.name: Defenders of ClayArt

37972.description: This is a simple roll-and-move game for very young children. Players roll an oversized die and move to the next space with a matching shape. The die is electronic and plays the "I Love You" song, adding incessant joy to the game. The first player to reach the end of the path wins.
37972.name: Barney Musical Parade Game

37973.name: Great Dynasties of Europe
37973.description:
"Theme: European Royal Houses 1300-1900. Each turn represents 25 years (roughly 1 generation). Starting in 1300 and ending in 1900. There are 24 turns."

There are three custom card decks used in the game, the Dynasty Deck, Territory Deck, and Event Deck.

The Dynasty Deck represents the Dynasties that the players can represent. Each Dynasty has a starting Territory and a Special Ability. The Dynasties included in the game are: Habsburg, Orange, Tudor, Burgundy, Stuart, Romanov, Grimaldi, Hohenzollern, Oldenburg, Bourbon, Capetian, and Valois.

Each card in the Territory Deck represents a Territory that can be owned by a player. Each Territory belongs to one of ten Regions.

The Event Deck contains a variety of random events. Each turn a card is drawn from the Event Deck and resolved.

"Victory: The player with the most Victory Tokens at the end of the game wins."

boardgamecompilation.157723: We Didn't Playtest This at All with Chaos Pack Expansion

37974.description:
Microbadge:

This is the first expansion for We Didn't Playtest This At All

It contains fifteen "random and awesome cards to enhance your copy of We Didn't Playtest This At All

The new cards add additional rules to the game. One is selected to be placed on the table at the start of each game or "If you're daring, place two."

Two blank cards to make your own rules are included.
37974.name: We Didn't Playtest This At All: Chaos Pack

31016.name: We Didn't Playtest This At All

boardgamefamily.8012: We Didn't Playtest This At All

37975.name: Heritage Games Italian Edition
37975.description:
The object of the game is for the player or team to advance around the game board by the roll of a die. While answering question pertinent to Italian-American culture, the first player or team to return to the Italy finish space wins the game. The game's 1492 questions explore the many significant contributions made by Italian and Italian-Americans in five categories: 1) History and Geography 2) Food, Music and Entertainment 3) Art, Science, and Literature 4) Sports and 5) Romans

TAG LINE ON BOX: The game that not only tests your knowledge, but gives you knowledge.

37976.name: Révolution
37976.description:
Contents: 8 sand timers, 1 board with 34 holes.

The game starts with the hourglasses set at opposite sides of the board, and each player at his turn moves and flips one of his 4 sand times along the lines of the board. Any hourglass out of sand is considered dead and pulled out of the game. The goal is to reach the opposite line of starting holes.

37977.name: Ripost
37977.description:
Contents : The board is a map representing two enemy territories, one lake, mountains, forests, roads, rivers, two citadels and 4 towns. Each player has 24 pawns: 8 infantry, 4 cavalry, 4 artillery, 3 engineering, 3 train, 2 infirmary. Also 2 special dices, several season cards, and map tokens.
This is a simplified wargame, with each side trying to take the opponents citadel or his two towns. Each turn, the player has 10 points that he might use to move his pawns, then if the target is in reach, he can fire.
The cards trigger events that affect the map (forest fires, plagues, etc.) Terrain also influences the way the pieces can move, and their vulnerability.

37978.name: Buried Treasure
37978.description: You have to play cards from your hand to build other players buried treasure. Each round one player gets to dig for treasure from his buried treasure pile, whatever he finds is his to keep but beware turn over the wrong card and another player may steal the remaining treasure or the rest of the dig may be washed away by a flood. A nice pile with lots of cards may be also full of cards from players trying to steal. Easy enough for children to play.

37979.name: Crummy Rummy
37979.description:
The game deck consists of cards with one or two letters each. A round begins with one card in the middle of the table. Players then add cards to the starting letter one at a time so as to produce legitimate words at each step.

Points are scored by making words that no other player can steal, meaning that no other player can make another word just by adding one card to the beginning or end of it. Points might also be scored by playing your last card, although rules are unclear on this point. They simply say, "Ten points are given to the first player to declare 'Crummy Rummy'" but they do not elaborate on the circumstances under which a player is entitled to so declare.

37980.name: Wise Guys
37980.description:
Wise Guys is a Dutch game published by Identity Games for "Spits", a newspaper.

The game comes with:
- a rather small game board (14x14 cm/5.5x5.5 inch)
- four pawns (blue, green, red, yellow)
- four "eens/oneens kaarten" (yes/no-cards)
- fifty-one question cards
- a four-page rulebook

The aim of the game is to be the first player to reach the finish line. All players start at the same starting point.

Each game round, one of the players takes a card and reads out loud one of the questions (yes-no type) on it. Each player then answers the question with yes or no, by putting his yes/no card in front of him/her (hidden for the other players).
The card reader then reads out loud the correct answer, which is printed on the back of the question card. One by one, each player announces whether he/she answered correctly or not. If the answer was correct, the player may move his pawn one step towards the finish line.

A player may lie about his answer. The card reader however has the right to check whether a player is sincere by asking to show his/her answer. If a player lied, his pawn has to move back two spaces. If the player was sincere, the card reader has to move his pawn one space backwards.

The first player to reach the finish line wins the game. If two or more players reach the finish line at the same time, it's a draw.

37981.description:
Suske en Wiske Spel is a Dutch game based on the comic Suske en Wiske (aka Bob et Bobette, Spike and Suzy, Willy and Wanda, Suske und Wiske).

The object of the game is to collect as many sets of cards as possible. Winner is the player that collects the most sets.

The players roll dice to move their pawn across the game board. Cards can be collected at some points on the board, by trading and by guessing. The game ends when there are no cards to left on the gameboard.
37981.name: Suske en Wiske Spel

37982.name: God Dice
37982.description: A strategic dice combat game, that pits the 2-4 players in mortal combat with one another. Players choose from six classes consisting of Hero, Monk, Assassin,Sage, Bowman and Cleric. Players roll nonstandard six sided dice attempting to qualify for special attacks and spells. Along with this, prior to combat, the special God Dice are rolled to see which character if any has found favor. In some cases this favor can be devastating. This is a great quick game of combat with a number of interesting strategic choices for combat. Will you be next legend or suffer the ultimate defeat?

37983.description: As former lab monkeys, players cooperate and compete to free imprisoned monkeys from a well-guarded testing facility. Of course, since the monkeys don’t have keys, they must use their creativity and the items found around the lab to pick, pry, and smash the cages open. The more monkeys you rescue, the more reward you receive.
37983.name: Monkey Lab

37984.name: Ancients D6
37984.description:
Ancients D6 is a set of miniature wargames rules for fighting battles set in ancient times. Armies are built out of stands ( multiple figures per stand ). On a turn all stands can be moved but commanders allow further movement for stands close enough. Combat is resolved through multiple rolls of standard (D6) dice. Roll to hit, roll for armour. Additional rolls are made for morale checks.

This game is free, web published and can be found amongst the other rules sets in the files section.

37985.description:
Alexander at Arbela (331 BC)
The map represents the area in which the battle of Gaugamela took place. The battlefield covered a large plain almost entirely flat, except a small area of irregular terrain on the one side of the map, which does not affect the game play.
Each hexagon of the map represents about 200 meters of actual terrain. Since the actual battlefield extended about 6 Km along, the map sheet is consisted of 30 hexagons along and 24 across.
In addition to the map there is included a sheet of paper with the necessary aids to illustrate various aspects of the game. There are the Combat Results Table, the Unit Value Table and Victory Conditions Table.
37985.name: Alexander at Arbela

37986.name: Der schiefe Turm von Pizza
37986.description:
From the publisher's website:

Build the leaning tower of pizza!

Collect the pizzas and put them, one on top of the other, to build the leaning tower. Be the first to deliver the order. The higher the tower, the more points you get. But be careful not to make the tower crash ...

The game consists of 80 wooden "pizzas", the order-cards and the scorecard. Turn by turn the players collect pizzas until an order can be completed by putting the pizzas on top of one of the towers. The higher the better, but once the tower crashes down, you loose your score, so be careful!

"The leaning tower of pizza" is a fun and thrilling game of skills for kids and grown-ups.

37987.description:
Subtitled "Trade and Intrigue at the Top of the World."

This is another of Blue Panther's limited edition games made of wood. The only thing not made of wood in this game are the rules. Beautiful production values and sure to be the best smelling game in any collection.

Players compete to establish trade routes across Nepal via tile placement. This will remind many players of tile placement train games. If the trade to an area gets too heavy, there's a population explosion that could lead to players' losing previously placed tiles until the population shrinks to a sustainable level.
37987.name: Nepal

37988.name: Trivial Pursuit: 25th Anniversary Edition
37988.description:
An update to the original Trivial Pursuit (1981).

While the core of Trivial Pursuit is still found in the 25th Anniversary Edition, there are a few differences from the original board game. The original six categories are still used: geography, entertainment, history, art & literature, science & nature, sport & leisure. Each category now has its own card, with six questions and three difficulty levels. What you roll determines the level of difficulty of the question. A roll of one or two results in an easy question, three or four a medium question, and five or six a hard question. Play in the middle of the board is just like the 1981 version where you roll the die, move your scoring token that number of spaces, and try to answer a question in an attempt to roll again or, in a special case, win a wedge of the corresponding color.

The object of the game is still to win all 6 wedges and answer one final question in the center of the board.

The biggest difference of this new version is the addition of an outside track, which you move a 2nd playing piece, a pawn of the same color, around. If you get a question correct, you get to move your pawn a certain number of spaces depending on the difficulty of the question answered. If your pawn lands in one of the four "specialty zones", you are granted a special power used either to help your chances to win the game or hurt your opponents. These zones are the Face-Off Zone, the Slow it Down Zone, The Easy Cheesy Zone, and Freebie Zone.

37989.name: Zoids
37989.description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Two Rival Teams of Zoid Warriors Face-off. Each figure represents a single Zoid. Victory: Destroy all opposing Zoids.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Several spaces are designated as obstacles (hills, crags, or cliffs.) Miniatures or counters are used to represent the Zoids. Each side starts with fifty points worth of Zoid Warriors. Each Zoid is rated for speed, hand-to-hand combat, toughness, and attack range.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

37990.name: X-Files
37990.description:
"Card game based on the first season of the X–Files."

Using an assortment of FBI agents (and a Scotland Yard Investigator), the players attempt to solve as many X-File cases as possible. The player who has solved the most cases when the deck runs out wins the game.

37991.name: Immortals
37991.description:
“Each player recruits a group of Immortals seeking to gain power over other such groups. Based on the Dungeons & Dragons RPG rule set ‘Wrath of the Immortals’. These associations of Immortals are variously known as Groups, Cliques (informal), and Councils (formal).”

The players represent a specific alignment: Lawful, Chaotic, or Neutral. Alignment affects the types of immortals which may be recruited by a player.

The winner is the first player to control one hundred Power Points worth of Immortals and Resource cards. A player may also win by reducing all opposing players to zero Power Points.

37992.name: In Nomine
37992.description:
“Two player card game based on the RPG In Nomine. One player controls a choir of Angels. The other player controls a band of Demons.”

The players assemble forces composed of Angels or Demons (celestial persona) and humans (persona) which battle for supremacy. The game can be won in one of three ways – by exhausting the opponent’s card deck, by having one of each of the seven types of celestial persona in play, or by having a human in play marked with sufficient Prophecy tokens.

37993.description:
This extension kit is just that,­ a kit to extend War in the Pacific (second edition) into late 1945 and 1946 making it possible to explore the possibilities of the war continuing without atomic intervention. The kit includes a new counter sheet for planes, ships, and other units scheduled to appear after August 1945. It also includes an additional set of the aircraft counter sheets for a total of five counter sheets, plus two more tactical island maps. The rules and charts booklet covers the additional rules needed to continue the war.

Contents:

32 Pages booklet
rule 74 "War extension: 1946"
optional rule 69 "Free Japanese Sub doctrine"
optional rule 6.4.9 "Supplemental Fighter Pilot Aces"
1946 charts
IJN Subron chart & tables
campaign reinforcement (9/45 to 12/46)

Adonard & Marcus maps (both on a letter size cardboard)
5 countersheets ("extension", 17, 18, 19, 20 sheets)




(source: Decision Games website & user's description)
37993.name: War in the Pacific Extension Kit

37994.name: Cosmic Tilt
37994.description:
Each player takes the role of an alien psychic and battles to be the last brain thinking. The magazine article included rules for the game, record sheets, and six special characters. Play also requires a standard deck of playing cards and some tokens.

The game was published October 18, 2002 in Pyramid Magazine.

37996.name: Watubi
37996.description:
Watubi, an African Strategy Game, is an abstract 2-player game played on a hexagonal board, in which players try to regroup their own scattered tribe-stones, using Halma style movement rules.

Players each place their own set of 13 tribe-stones onto the predefined starting places. These tribe-stones have two sides: one side with a tribe-symbol, and one without. All stones start the game with the tribe-symbol face-up, but every time that a stone is jumped over, it flips over, either hiding the tribe-symbol, or revealing it again. A stone that jumps over another stone always ends its move with the tribe-symbol revealed.

To win the game, a player must get at least 7 own stones into a single grouping. This can be anywhere on the board, with the catch that only stones that show the own tribe-symbol count, and all of them must touch.

Movement rules are simple. A stone either moves to a free hexagon immediately next to the field it occupies, ending its movement with the same side face-up. Or it hops over a neighbouring stone, regardless of who it belongs to, flipping every stone it jumps over, and ending its movement with its own tribe-symbol face-up. Like Halma, hopping is only possible if the field directly behind the jumped stone is unoccupied, and you are allowed to keep hopping over other stones if the board allows it, as long as you never pass the same hexagon twice. You are not forced to jump over a piece if you don't want to, and you can stop jumping at any point that suits you.

The board is made out of felt, the tribe-stones come in 2 colours and are made out of wood.

ADDITIONAL INFO:

language skill needed: language neutral. Game comes with German rules.
english translation: None available.

37997.description:
Zombie Cinema is a boardgame for 3-6 players, Ages 12 and up. One game takes 2-3 hours, all told. Learning the game takes ten minutes. The game is a cooperative storytelling exercise wherein the players create a story very much like a zombie movie.

What it says on the box

Nobody knew when it started, or why. Perhaps the lonely death of a spinster was one too much for angels to bear, or a chemical leak in the ground-water had unexpected consequences. Only one thing is certain: now the dead walk.

This story game is about the zombie apocalypse and the desperate choices of the survivors. Not only do these characters scramble over each other trying to find safety, but they may also cooperate and even sacrifice themselves so at least a few might survive the story.

Zombie Cinema is quick to set up, easy to learn and it's designed to play from start to finish in one evening, making for an excellent party game or a first step into a new hobby. The game box includes everything required to create stories of survival horror with your friends.

Game Components:
27 Cinema Cards
1 Game Board
6 Character Pawns
6 Dice
1 Zombie Pawn
1 Round Marker
1 Rules Sheet

Packaged in a VHS tape case, making it look like a zombie movie.
37997.name: Zombie Cinema

37998.name: Carnage and Glory II
37998.description: Carnage & Glory II is an easy to learn and easy to play computer moderated rule system suitable for both the novice and experienced player. There are no complex charts or book-keeping and accounting required as Carnage & Glory II maintains all the relevant information regarding the status of the combat units and general officers within the system database. Complex concepts such as variable weather and ground conditions, heat exhaustion, ammunition usage, mental and physical fatigue and variable morale are easily accommodated by the system. By eliminating the emphasis on dice and charts typical of more traditional wargames, the sole focus of the game becomes the tactical movement and engagement of the forces under your command. The result is a thoroughly enjoyable and stimulating wargame experience.

37999.description:
Poland 1939 is an extension part/ module to the "Down In Flames"-Series - Volume 1: Rise of the Luftwaffe game by GMT. This module is found in RBM/GMT's C3i Magazine Nr18.

The German invasion of Poland which began on September 1st, 1939 was the world's first demonstration of "Blitzkrieg", the "lightning war". The sudden onslaught stunned the Poles, who offered little resistance to the Germans' panzer divisions. The invaders quickly penetrated into the into the interior, reaching Warsaw in just over a week. The rapidity of the German troops advance was in large part due to support from the Luftwaffe. Under attack by both air and armor, the Polish army and air force slowly collapsed. On September 17th, 1939, the USSR attacked Poland, shattering the country's morale. The campaign was effectively over in just three weeks, long before France and Britain could fulfill their promises to come to the aid of Poland.

"Down in Flames" series is a card-driven game that simulate WW2 air combat.
37999.name: Down In Flames: Poland 1939
